text:
"Death has a pretty busy - if somewhat monotonous
- job.

On average, they process 165,000 accounts
per day.

Some of the filings are pretty routine: Alzheimer's,
cancer, diabetes, drug overdoses, and violence

kill people at roughly the same rates all
year round.

But other causes of death vary wildly at different
times of year - specifically, Death's work
piles up in winter.

Deaths from flu and pneumonia increase dramatically
during winter months because the bugs that

cause those infections survive better in colder,
drier weather and jump from host to host more
easily as people crowd together indoors.

But that only accounts for 20% of Winter’s
extra death toll.

What really keeps Death late at the office
is that deaths from heart attacks and strokes
also rise when it's chilly.

That’s because in the cold, our blood vessels
constrict to keep us from losing precious
heat to the outside world - which is great!
Kind of.

You see, narrower vessels also mean that our
platelets - sticky blood cells that we sometimes

want to clump together to form clots - are
more likely to clump together when we don't

want them to, blocking arteries and causing
deadly heart attacks and strokes.

The good news is that in the warmer summer
months, those cold-related deaths let up and
the Reaper gets a reprieve (and so do we).

Though deaths from a few other causes rise
a little bit in the summer - there are more

deadly car accidents because we tend to drive
more; there are more drownings because we

tend to swim more, and there are more fatal
heat strokes because it’s hotter - they

don’t even come close to the mountain of
extra Winter deaths.

In all, roughly 30,000 more people worldwide
die every day in the winter than they do in
the summer.
That’s 20% more deaths!

So you might think that at non-Winter times
of year, Death would get to relax.

But because the hemispheres of the world experience
seasons at opposite times, when it’s Summer

in one side of the world, it’s Winter in
the other.
So for Death, it’s always pretty grim."

What’s also grim is the state of my browser
tab management, it seems I always have at
least 20 open!

But thanks to Tab for a Cause, this video’s
sponsor, each tab I open donates money to

fantastic charities like Water.org and The
Foundation to Decrease Worldsuck, including

the 2,600 tabs I’ve opened since the last
Tab for a Cause sponsored video in March!

If you, like me, open up way too many tabs,
you can feel good about it by going to tabforacause.org/MinuteEarth2
and downloading the extension now.
That’s tabforacause.org/MinuteEarth2.
